column1: TA4.28;By 31 December 2030
column2: in each safe and secure parking area at least four publicly accessible recharging stations dedicated to heavy-duty electric vehicles with an individual power output of at least 100 kW are deployed.;TA3.29;+;The deployment of recharging stations for heavy-duty electric vehicles could lead to an increase in the demand for recycled materials
column3: such as metals
column4: which could have a positive impact on the target of reducing waste and increasing recycling rates. This is because the production of new recharging stations would require the use of recycled materials
column5: thereby reducing the need for primary materials and decreasing waste.

column1: TA4.29;By 31 December 2030
column2: in each urban node publicly accessible recharging points dedicated to heavy-duty electric vehicles with an aggregated power output of at least 1 800 kW are deployed.;TA3.30;+;The deployment of recharging points for heavy-duty electric vehicles in urban nodes could lead to an increase in the demand for recycled materials
column3: such as metals
column4: which could have a positive impact on the target of reducing waste and increasing recycling rates. This is because the production of new recharging points would require the use of recycled materials
column5: thereby reducing the need for primary materials and decreasing waste.

column1: TA4.30;Member States shall ensure that
column2: by 31 December 2030
column3: at least one publicly accessible hydrogen refuelling station is deployed in each urban node.;TA3.31;+;The deployment of hydrogen refuelling stations in urban nodes could lead to an increase in the demand for recycled materials
column5: which could have a positive impact on the target of reducing waste and increasing recycling rates. This is because the production of new hydrogen refuelling stations would require the use of recycled materials
column6: thereby reducing the need for primary materials and decreasing waste.

column1: TA4.31;Member States shall ensure that
column2: by 31 December 2030
column3: publicly accessible hydrogen refuelling stations with a total capacity of at least 1 tonne per day
column4: and equipped with at least a 700 bar dispenser
column5: are deployed at least every 200 km along the TEN-T (Trans-European Transport Network) core network.;TA3.32;+;The deployment of hydrogen refuelling stations along the TEN-T core network could lead to an increase in the demand for recycled materials
column7: which could have a positive impact on the target of reducing waste and increasing recycling rates. This is because the production of new hydrogen refuelling stations would require the use of recycled materials
column8: thereby reducing the need for primary materials and decreasing waste.

column1: TA4.32;States shall ensure that
column2: at all airports of the TEN-T core network and TEN-T comprehensive network
column3: the provision of electricity supply to stationary aircraft is ensured by 31 December 2029
column4: at all aircraft remote stands used for commercial air transport operations to embark or disembark passengers or to load or unload goods.;TA3.33;+;The provision of electricity supply to stationary aircraft could lead to an increase in the demand for recycled materials
column6: which could have a positive impact on the target of reducing waste and increasing recycling rates. This is because the production of new electricity supply systems would require the use of recycled materials
column7: thereby reducing the need for primary materials and decreasing waste.

column1: TA4.33;Member States shall ensure that at least one installation providing shore-side electricity supply to inland waterway vessels is deployed at all TEN-T core inland waterway ports by 1 January 2025; at least one installation providing shore-side electricity supply to inland waterway vessels is deployed at all TEN-T comprehensive inland waterway ports by 1 January 2030.;TA3.34;+;The deployment of shore-side electricity supply installations for inland waterway vessels could lead to an increase in the demand for recycled materials
column2: such as metals
column3: which could have a positive impact on the target of reducing waste and increasing recycling rates. This is because the production of new installations would require the use of recycled materials
column4: thereby reducing the need for primary materials and decreasing waste.

column1: TA4.34;Member States shall ensure that a minimum shore-side electricity supply for seagoing container ships and seagoing passenger ships is provided in TEN-T maritime ports.;TA3.35;+;The provision of shore-side electricity supply for seagoing container ships and seagoing passenger ships could lead to an increase in the demand for recycled materials
column2: such as metals
column3: which could have a positive impact on the target of reducing waste and increasing recycling rates. This is because the production of new electricity supply systems would require the use of recycled materials
column4: thereby reducing the need for primary materials and decreasing waste.

column1: TA4.55;Zero-emission in urban logistics;TA5.6;+;The promotion of zero-emission urban logistics could lead to an increase in the demand for sustainable and organic food production
column2: which could have a positive impact on the target of increasing organic farming and reducing the use of chemical pesticides. This is because zero-emission urban logistics would require the use of electric or hybrid vehicles
column3: which could lead to a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and air pollution
column4: making it easier to promote sustainable and organic food production.

column1: TA5.2;Reduce overall EU sales of antimicrobials for farmed animals and in aquaculture by 50% by 2030.;TA5.4;-;The reduction of antimicrobials for farmed animals and in aquaculture could lead to an increase in the use of alternative methods for disease prevention and treatment
column2: such as the use of more hazardous pesticides
column3: which could have a negative impact on the target of reducing the use of more hazardous pesticides. This is because the reduction of antimicrobials could lead to an increase in the use of alternative methods that may be more harmful to the environment and human health.

column1: TA5.3;Reduce nutrient losses by at least 50%
column2: while ensuring that there is no deterioration in soil fertility.;TA5.9;-;The reduction of nutrient losses could lead to a decrease in the use of organic farming methods
column3: which could have a negative impact on the target of increasing organic farming. This is because the reduction of nutrient losses could lead to an increase in the use of conventional farming methods that rely on synthetic fertilizers
column4: which could lead to a decrease in organic farming.

column1: TA5.4;Reduce by 50% the use of more hazardous pesticides;TA5.2;-;The reduction of more hazardous pesticides could lead to an increase in the use of antimicrobials for farmed animals and in aquaculture
column2: which could have a negative impact on the target of reducing overall EU sales of antimicrobials. This is because the reduction of more hazardous pesticides could lead to an increase in the use of alternative methods for disease prevention and treatment
column3: such as the use of antimicrobials.

column1: TA5.5;Reduce by 50% the use and risk of chemical pesticides;TA5.9;-;The reduction of chemical pesticides could lead to a decrease in the use of organic farming methods
column2: which could have a negative impact on the target of increasing organic farming. This is because the reduction of chemical pesticides could lead to an increase in the use of conventional farming methods that rely on synthetic fertilizers
column3: which could lead to a decrease in organic farming.

column1: TA5.6;Aquatic living resources: Increase sustainable fishing and aquaculture. Bring fish stocks to sustainable levels. Significant increase in organic aquaculture.;TA5.7;-;The increase in sustainable fishing and aquaculture could lead to an increase in greenhouse gas emissions from the food system
column2: which could have a negative impact on the target of reducing net greenhouse gas emissions to at least 55% below 1990 levels by 2030. This is because the production of fish and other seafood could lead to an increase in energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions.

column1: TA5.7;Ensure that agriculture
column2: fisheries and aquaculture
column3: and the food value chain contribute to the target of reducing net greenhouse gas emissions to at least 55% below 1990 levels by 2030 and to the achievement of the objective for a climate-neutral Union in 2050.;TA5.6;-;The reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from the food system could lead to a decrease in the production of fish and other seafood
column4: which could have a negative impact on the target of increasing sustainable fishing and aquaculture. This is because the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions could lead to an increase in the use of alternative protein sources
column6: which could lead to a decrease in the demand for fish and other seafood.

column1: TA5.8;Water: Preserving freshwater
column2: boosting water reuse in agriculture.;TA5.9;-;The preservation of freshwater and boosting of water reuse in agriculture could lead to a decrease in the use of organic farming methods
column3: which could have a negative impact on the target of increasing organic farming. This is because the preservation of freshwater and boosting of water reuse could lead to an increase in the use of conventional farming methods that rely on synthetic fertilizers
column4: which could lead to a decrease in organic farming.

column1: TA5.9;Increase organic farming with the aim to achieve at least 25% of total farmland under organic farming by 2030;TA5.3;+;The increase in organic farming could lead to a reduction in nutrient losses
column2: which could have a positive impact on the target of reducing nutrient losses by at least 50%. This is because organic farming methods tend to use more natural and organic fertilizers
column3: which could lead to a reduction in nutrient losses.

column1: TA5.10;Energy: Increase renewable energy in the agriculture and food sector.;TA5.7;+;The increase in renewable energy in the agriculture and food sector could lead to a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions from the food system
column2: which could have a positive impact on the target of reducing net greenhouse gas emissions to at least 55% below 1990 levels by 2030. This is because the use of renewable energy could lead to a reduction in energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions from the food system.

column1: TA3.23;All recycling shall achieve at least the following targets for recovery of materials
column2: 50% for lithium
column3: no later than 31 December 2027; and 80% for lithium no later than 31 December 2031.;TA4.28;-;The increase in recycling targets for lithium could lead to an increase in the cost of producing electric vehicles
column4: which could have a negative impact on the target of deploying at least four publicly accessible recharging stations dedicated to heavy-duty electric vehicles with an individual power output of at least 100 kW in each safe and secure parking area. This is because the increase in recycling targets could lead to an increase in the cost of lithium
column5: which could make electric vehicles more expensive and less competitive.

column1: TA3.24;Reduce the generation of food waste in processing and manufacturing by 10% in comparison to the amount generated in 2020;TA5.5;+;The reduction of food waste could lead to a reduction in the use of chemical pesticides
column2: which could have a positive impact on the target of reducing the use and risk of chemical pesticides. This is because the reduction of food waste could lead to a reduction in the production of food
column3: which could lead to a reduction in the use of chemical pesticides.

column1: TA3.25;Reduce the generation of food waste per capita
column2: jointly in retail and other distribution of food
column3: in restaurants and food services and in households
column4: by 30% in comparison to the amount generated in 2020;TA5.5;+;The reduction of food waste could lead to a reduction in the use of chemical pesticides
column5: which could have a positive impact on the target of reducing the use and risk of chemical pesticides. This is because the reduction of food waste could lead to a reduction in the production of food
column6: which could lead to a reduction in the use of chemical pesticides.

column1: TA3.27;All packaging shall be recyclable;TA5.9;-;The increase in recyclable packaging could lead to an increase in the use of organic farming methods
column2: which could have a negative impact on the target of increasing organic farming. This is because the increase in recyclable packaging could lead to an increase in the use of conventional farming methods that rely on synthetic fertilizers
column3: which could lead to a decrease in organic farming.

column1: TA3.28;The plastic part in packaging shall contain the following minimum percentage of recycled content recovered from post-consumer plastic waste;TA5.9;-;The increase in recycled content in packaging could lead to an increase in the use of organic farming methods
column2: which could have a negative impact on the target of increasing organic farming. This is because the increase in recycled content could lead to an increase in the use of conventional farming methods that rely on synthetic fertilizers
column3: which could lead to a decrease in organic farming.

column1: TA3.29;Member States shall take measures to achieve a sustained reduction in the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags on their territory;TA5.5;+;The reduction in the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags could lead to a reduction in the use of chemical pesticides
column2: which could have a positive impact on the target of reducing the use and risk of chemical pesticides. This is because the reduction in plastic carrier bags could lead to a reduction in the production of food
column3: which could lead to a reduction in the use of chemical pesticides.

column1: TA3.30;Each Member State shall reduce the packaging waste generated per capita
column2: as compared to the packaging waste generated per capita in 2018 as reported to the Commission in accordance with Decision 2005/270/EC by 5% by 2030; 10% by 2035; 15% by 2040;TA5.9;-;The reduction in packaging waste could lead to an increase in the use of organic farming methods
column3: which could have a negative impact on the target of increasing organic farming. This is because the reduction in packaging waste could lead to an increase in the use of conventional farming methods that rely on synthetic fertilizers
column4: which could lead to a decrease in organic farming.

column1: TA3.31;Member States shall take the necessary measures to attain the recycling targets of 65% by weight of all packaging waste generated by 31 December 2025; and of 70% by weight of all packaging waste generated by 31 December 2030.;TA5.9;-;The increase in recycling targets for packaging waste could lead to an increase in the use of organic farming methods

column3: which could lead to a decrease in organic farming.

column1: TA3.38;Each vehicle belonging to a vehicle type that is type-approved as of [the first day of the month following 72 months after the date of entry into force of this Regulation] under Regulation (EU) 2018/858 shall be constructed so that it is: (a) reusable/recyclable to a minimum of 85% by mass; (b) reusable/recoverable to a minimum of 95 % by mass.;TA5.9;-;The increase in recycling targets for vehicles could lead to an increase in the use of organic farming methods
